awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF:  Role of Land-atmosphere Processes in Climate Models' Projections of the West African Monsoon
awd_abstract_narration: The goal of this project is to advance understanding of the physical processes responsible for uncertainties in the projected evolution of the West Africa Monsoon (WAM) in climate models. Making use of simulations from the recent fifth phase of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5), this project proposes to explore the hypothesis that differences in the simulation of land-atmosphere processes in climate models play a role in the spread of WAM projections across models. Expected outcomes of this activity include: (i) an evaluation of WAM evolution in climate change simulations from the latest generation of climate models; (ii) a characterization of simulated land-atmosphere processes in these models; and (iii) an estimation of how inter-model variability with respect to these processes relates to the spread in WAM projections. Regardless of whether simulated land-atmosphere processes are found to explain the scatter in WAM projections in climate models, this project will lead to increased understanding of how models simulate fundamental coupled land-atmosphere processes as well as the uncertainty of such processes across the CMIP5 ensemble.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
West Africa receives most of its rainfall from the West African Monsoon during the (Northern Hemisphere) summer. Local populations rely heavily on this precipitation for their livelihood. As a result, past dry spells of the Monsoon, such as the drought of the 70’s and 80’s, have had dire humanitarian consequences, and the region is vulnerable to potential adverse future changes in the Monsoon in the context of climate change. Yet, the physical mechanisms governing the monsoon behavior and its variations are not fully understood, and simulations from climate models give contrasting results regarding the future evolution of the Monsoon in a warmer climate.

In this context, the research conducted under this Award aimed at improving our understanding of the West African Monsoon and its future under climate change.

The focus was on investigating the role of physical interactions between soil moisture and the atmosphere. These processes are important for surface climate. It is easy to see how changes in soil moisture are driven by variations in precipitation; what is perhaps less intuitive is that, in turn, changes in soil moisture modulate fluxes of water and heat from the surface to the atmosphere, such as evaporation – particularly so in dry regions like West Africa.  As a result, soil moisture variations can feedback on surface climatic conditions, such as temperature and humidity. Previous studies have suggested that such processes (referred to as soil moisture-atmosphere interactions) may play an important role in West Africa, but there had been no detailed investigation of their exact role in the monsoon and its changes with global warming.

To investigate this issue, I relied on idealized climate model simulations performed by several modeling centers in the context of a model inter-comparison project. In this experiment, each model had performed a pair of global climate simulations from the present to the future, with either interactive soil moisture (that is, with soil moisture-atmosphere interactions accounted for) or with non-interactive soil moisture, fixed to present-time levels (that is, with the same interactions turned off). Comparing how the Monsoon was simulated in the present in these two configurations allowed me to isolate the role of soil moisture-atmosphere interactions in the present-day, climatological characteristics of the Monsoon, in several (6) climate models at the same time. I found that, on average and with good consistency across models, soil moisture processes led to the simulated monsoon starting slightly earlier, but being overall weaker, in particular at the northern edge of the monsoon domain. In terms of processes, an original aspect of these findings was that these impacts did not stem from the impacts of soil moisture on local evaporation and water recycling into precipitation, but rather were linked to how soil moisture variations influence large-scale surface temperature patterns, and thus the large-scale atmospheric circulation of the monsoon. These results improve our understanding of the physical processes shaping the Monsoon.

Further, comparison of the two types of simulations in the future indicated that when soil moisture-atmosphere interactions are artificially disabled, models project a consistent increase of precipitation over West Africa, as opposed to uncertain changes of both signs in simulations with interactive soil moisture (representative of climate model uncertainties regarding the future of the Monsoon, as mentioned above). This effect arose mostly from the feedback of long-term soil moisture change on the monsoon. These results suggest that soil moisture atmosphere interactions play an important role in precipitation projections over West Africa, and that reducing uncertainties there will require, amongst other factors, better understanding and constraining of simulated land-atmosphere feedbacks in climate model.

Finally, in an extension of the results above, the same set of simulations was used in a study of a more global nature, focusing on the changes in climate aridity under global warming over land as a whole. Climate model projections consistently indicate that climatic aridity, defined in terms of atmospheric supply (precipitation, P) and demand (potential evapotranspiration, Ep) of water at the land surface, will increase globally, on average, in a warmer world, as Ep increases faster with temperature than P (even if average P is projected to increase, too). Yet, the fundamental processes underlying these projections remain to be elucidated. Recent studies had argued that this increasing-aridity response over land was, somewhat paradoxically, rooted in relatively simple, robust ocean-atmosphere processes associated with ocean warming, independent of the land surface. I showed that while ocean warming did play a driving role, the aridity response was also substantially amplified by land–atmosphere feedbacks associated with the land surface’s response to climate: global soil moisture is projected to decrease in the future, and global aridity is enhanced by the feedbacks of this projected soil moisture decrease on land surface temperature, relative humidity and precipitation.
